--- In n=
eat@yahoogroups.com, "joel278" <lehman.154@...> wrote:
>
> Ken Stanley and =
I are pleased to annouce our new article, "Evolvability is Inevitable: Incr=
easing Evolvability without the Pressure to Adapt," which was published tod=
ay in PLoS ONE. The paper can be viewed at: 
> 
> http://dx.plos.org/10.137=
1/journal.pone.0062186
> 
> The article applies both abstract simulations a=
nd neuroevolution to explore a non-adaptive explanation for increasing evol=
vability in nature. Interestingy, understanding evolvability (the capacity =
to further evolve) might lead not only to better understanding how complex =
organisms evolve in nature, but may also provide insight into how to design=
 evolutionary algorithms that are better able to evolve complex artifacts.
=
> 
> Most existing theories for evolvability increase depend upon particula=
r selective scenarios, such as a species surviving through constantly chang=
ing environments. However, the insight in the article is that evolvability =
can instead arise spontaneously without natural selection acting at all. Th=
e main idea is that if evolvability is heritable, then evolvable organisms =
separate themselves naturally from less evolvable organisms over time simpl=
y by their children becoming increasingly diverse and thereby spreading fur=
ther through the space of possible phenotypes. That is, the space of phenot=
ypes itself can act like a filter that distinguishes evolvability.
> 
> In =
this way, when novel phenotypes appear in the future, they are most likely =
descendents of those that were evolvable in the past. The result is that ev=
olvable species accumulate over time even without selective pressure. This =
idea is supported by a variety of simulations where evolvability increases =
without any pressure for organisms to out-compete each other.
> 
> Those fa=
miliar with novelty search will notice some conceptual parallels with Ken's=
 and my previous work on searching without objectives. Like novelty search,=
 the proposed non-adaptive hypothesis for evolvability may invite some cont=
roversy because adaptive explanations for evolvability are intuitive and wi=
dely-held. For example, researchers often worry about what kind of selectiv=
e pressure will lead to evolvability, even in discussions in this group. On=
e implication of this work could be that such worrying is unwarranted becau=
se the best way to get evolvability may sometimes be to stop trying to sele=
ct for it. In any case, despite any potential controversy, we hope that thi=
s alternate perspective leads to constructive discussion and demonstrates t=
he need to question the assumption that evolvability requires particular se=
lective scenarios for it to increase.
> 
> Joel
